source.name: NYC Department of Sanitation (DSNY)
source.notes: Based on official DSNY recycling, composting, and waste disposal guidelines. NYC uses a dual-bin recycling system: BLUE bin for metal/glass/plastic/cartons and GREEN bin for paper/cardboard only.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse the bottle
Replace the cap; leave caps on
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Only rigid plastic bottles; no flexible plastic
Labels can stay on
commonMistakes: Don't put in the GREEN bin; that's for paper only
Don't include flexible squeeze pouches
Don't include bottles with product still inside

materials.name: Rigid plastic containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Must be rigid plastic; if you can't easily crumple it, it's rigid
Includes yogurt cups, deli containers, butter tubs
commonMistakes: Don't include flexible or film plastic
Don't include styrofoam containers; styrofoam is banned in NYC
Don't put in the GREEN bin; that's for paper only

materials.name: Plastic clamshell containers
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Rigid clear plastic hinged containers are accepted
Includes berry containers, salad boxes, bakery boxes
commonMistakes: Don't include styrofoam clamshells; those are banned in NYC and go in trash
Don't put in the GREEN bin

materials.name: Plastic jugs
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace the cap
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Includes milk jugs, water jugs, juice jugs
commonMistakes: Don't put in the GREEN bin; that's for paper only

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Metal lids can stay on or be recycled separately
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: All colors of glass are accepted
NYC accepts glass bottles and jars only; not other types of glass
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap it and place in trash
Don't include window glass, mirrors, ceramics, or Pyrex
Don't include drinking glasses or light bulbs
Don't put in the GREEN bin; that's for paper only

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Aluminum cans are among the most valuable recyclables
Labels can stay on
NY has a 5Â¢ bottle deposit; you can also return for refund
commonMistakes: Don't crush cans in NYC; they need to be identifiable for sorting
Don't put in the GREEN bin

materials.name: Steel and tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Both steel and tin-plated cans are accepted
If a magnet sticks to it, it's steel
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still inside
Don't put in the GREEN bin

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up clean foil into a fist-sized ball
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Must be clean; greasy or food-caked foil goes in trash or brown bin
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil covered in baked-on grease; trash it
Don't put tiny scraps in recycling; ball them together

materials.name: Aluminum trays and pans
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: NYC accepts clean aluminum trays and pans; unlike some other cities
commonMistakes: Don't recycle trays caked with food; rinse them first
Don't put in the GREEN bin

materials.name: Metal lids and caps
instructions: Collect small metal lids inside a steel can
Crimp the can closed to keep lids inside
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Loose small metal pieces fall through sorting screens; always contain them
commonMistakes: Don't toss loose metal lids into recycling; they fall through the screens

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Do NOT puncture the can
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Only empty aerosol cans; partial cans are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cans that still have pressure; they're hazardous
Don't puncture aerosol cans

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace the cap if it has one
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons); NOT the green bin
notes: Cartons go in the BLUE bin in NYC, not with paper
Includes gable-top (refrigerated) and aseptic (shelf-stable) cartons
commonMistakes: Don't put cartons in the GREEN bin; despite being made of paper, they go in BLUE
Don't flatten cartons; they need to be 3D for sorting

materials.name: Cleaning product bottles
instructions: Empty completely
Rinse briefly
Leave the spray trigger on
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Rigid plastic cleaning bottles are recyclable in NYC
commonMistakes: Don't recycle bottles that still contain product
Don't put in the GREEN bin

materials.name: Prescription bottles
instructions: Remove the label (it contains personal health info)
Rinse out residue
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Rigid plastic; accepted in NYC recycling
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove the label with your personal information
Don't put medications in recycling; those need safe disposal

materials.name: Bottle caps (plastic)
instructions: Leave plastic caps ON their bottles
Recycle the whole bottle with cap in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Loose caps fall through sorting screens; always leave them on the bottle
commonMistakes: Don't remove the cap and toss it in separately; leave it on the bottle

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (styrofoam, bubble wrap, air pillows)
Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY); NOT the blue bin
notes: NYC separates paper from other recyclables; cardboard goes in the GREEN bin
Flatten boxes so they fit in the bin
commonMistakes: Don't put cardboard in the BLUE bin; it goes in GREEN
Don't include cardboard soaked with grease; greasy portions go in brown bin (compost)
Remove all styrofoam, bubble wrap, and plastic inserts

materials.name: Paperboard boxes (cereal boxes, tissue boxes)
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove any plastic liners or windows
Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
notes: Paperboard is thinner than corrugated cardboard but still goes in the GREEN bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE bin; paper products go in GREEN
Don't include frozen food boxes; those have a moisture coating and go in trash

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Place directly in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
Do NOT bag newspapers in plastic bags
notes: Newspapers are one of the most valuable paper recyclables
Inserts and circulars can stay in
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE bin; newspapers go in GREEN
Don't bag them in plastic bags; place loose in the green bin

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
Glossy coating is fine; still recyclable
notes: Staples can stay in; they're removed during processing
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE bin; magazines go in GREEN
Don't remove staples; they're handled at the facility

materials.name: Office and printer paper
instructions: Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
notes: Includes white and colored paper
Staples and paper clips can stay
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE bin; all paper goes in GREEN
Don't include paper contaminated with food or grease

materials.name: Mail and envelopes
instructions: Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
Window envelopes are fine; the plastic window is removed during processing
notes: Shred sensitive mail first if needed, then place shreds in a paper bag in the GREEN bin
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE bin; paper goes in GREEN
Don't include padded/bubble mailers; those go in trash

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
Can be used to contain shredded paper
notes: Clean paper bags are recyclable; food-soiled bags can go in the brown bin (compost)
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE bin; paper bags go in GREEN
Grease-soaked bags go in the brown compost bin instead

materials.name: Books
instructions: Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
Hardcovers can go in as-is; the cover is removed during processing
notes: Consider donating books in good condition to the New York Public Library or local Little Free Library first
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE bin; books go in GREEN

materials.name: Paper egg cartons
instructions: Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
notes: Paper/cardboard egg cartons only; styrofoam egg cartons go in trash (banned in NYC)
Can also be composted in the brown bin
commonMistakes: Don't recycle styrofoam egg cartons; those are banned and go in trash
Don't put in the BLUE bin

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Plain paper wrapping goes in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
Remove all tape, ribbons, and bows first
notes: Metallic, glittery, or plastic-coated wrapping paper is NOT recyclable; trash it
commonMistakes: Don't recycle metallic or glittery wrapping paper; it goes in trash
Don't include ribbons or bows; those go in trash

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place shredded paper inside a paper bag
Fold the top of the bag closed
Place the bag in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
notes: Loose shredded paper jams machinery; always bag it in a paper bag
commonMistakes: Don't dump loose shredded paper in the bin
Don't use a plastic bag; use a paper bag

materials.name: Phone books and directories
instructions: Place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
notes: Spine glue is removed during processing
commonMistakes: Don't put in the BLUE bin

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Clean top of the box: flatten and place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
Greasy bottom of the box: place in BROWN bin (compost)
If the entire box is greasy, put the whole thing in the BROWN bin
notes: NYC lets you split the box; clean portions recycle, greasy portions compost
commonMistakes: Don't put the greasy part in the GREEN bin; grease contaminates paper recycling
Don't put the clean part in the BLUE bin; it's paper, so it goes in GREEN

materials.name: Food scraps (general)
instructions: Place in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
No need to separate; all food scraps are accepted
Can be placed loose or in a bag lined with newspaper
notes: NYC's curbside composting program accepts ALL food scraps including meat, dairy, and bones
Expanding to all five boroughs
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the recycling bins
Don't use plastic bags to line the brown bin; use newspaper or compostable bags

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
notes: All fruit and vegetable scraps including peels, cores, rinds, and seeds
commonMistakes: Don't put produce stickers in compost; peel them off first

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
instructions: Place coffee grounds and paper filters in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
notes: Paper filters are compostable
K-Cup pods must be emptied; grounds in brown bin, pod in trash
commonMistakes: Don't compost K-Cup plastic pods; only the grounds inside

materials.name: Tea bags
instructions: Place in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
Remove any staples or tags if possible
notes: Most tea bags are compostable, though some contain plastic mesh; those go in trash
commonMistakes: Check if the tea bag is silky/plastic mesh; those can't be composted

materials.name: Eggshells
instructions: Place in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
notes: Eggshells add calcium to compost
commonMistakes: Don't put eggs in recycling; they go in the brown compost bin

materials.name: Meat, bones, and dairy
instructions: Place in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
NYC's industrial composting accepts ALL food including meat, bones, and dairy
notes: Unlike backyard composting, NYC's industrial process handles meat and dairy
commonMistakes: Don't pour liquid grease in the brown bin; absorb it with newspaper first or let it solidify

materials.name: Bread, pasta, rice, and grains
instructions: Place in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
notes: Includes cooked and uncooked bread, pasta, rice, and cereals
commonMistakes: Don't put these in the trash; they're compostable

materials.name: Food-soiled paper (napkins, paper towels, paper plates)
instructions: Place in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
Includes napkins, paper towels, paper plates, and tissues
notes: Food-soiled paper cannot be recycled but CAN be composted
Unsoiled paper towels and tissues can also go in the brown bin
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled paper in the GREEN recycling bin; it contaminates paper recycling
Don't put paper towels in the BLUE bin either

materials.name: Yard waste (leaves, grass, branches)
instructions: Place in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
Large branches: cut to 4-foot lengths, tie in bundles, place next to the brown bin
notes: Seasonal leaf collection may also be available; check DSNY schedule
commonMistakes: Don't bag yard waste in plastic bags
Don't include treated or painted wood

materials.name: Houseplants and flowers
instructions: Remove from the pot; plant matter goes in BROWN bin (organics/compost)
Clay or plastic pots go in trash (rigid plastic pots MAY go in blue bin)
notes: Soil can go in the brown bin with the plant
commonMistakes: Don't put the plastic or clay pot in the brown bin

materials.name: Polystyrene foam (Styrofoam)
instructions: Place in regular trash
Styrofoam is BANNED in NYC; businesses cannot distribute it
Any styrofoam you encounter still goes in the trash; it is not recyclable
notes: NYC banned single-use styrofoam food containers and packing peanuts
Despite the ban, you may still receive styrofoam from deliveries; it goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't put styrofoam in the BLUE or GREEN recycling bins
Don't assume styrofoam can be composted; it cannot

materials.name: Plastic bags
instructions: Do NOT place in any curbside recycling bin
Return clean, dry plastic bags to store drop-off bins (most grocery stores have them)
If no drop-off available, place in regular trash
notes: Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant in NYC recycling; they jam sorting machinery
Many NYC stores (Target, Whole Foods, Key Food) have bag return bins at the entrance
commonMistakes: Never bag your recyclables in plastic bags; empty items directly into the bins
Don't put any plastic film, bags, or wrap in curbside recycling

materials.name: Plastic film and wrap
instructions: Place in regular trash
Bubble wrap and air pillows: deflate first to save space
Some clean film can go to store drop-off with plastic bags
notes: Flexible plastic cannot go in curbside recycling in NYC
commonMistakes: Don't put any flexible plastic in the BLUE or GREEN bins
Don't put bubble wrap in recycling

materials.name: Candy wrappers, chip bags, and snack pouches
instructions: Place in regular trash
Multi-layer flexible packaging; not recyclable
notes: These look metallic but are actually layers of plastic and aluminum fused together; not separable
commonMistakes: Don't put chip bags in recycling; they are NOT aluminum
Don't put candy wrappers in recycling

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Lined paper cups: place in regular trash
Plastic lids: place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
Paper sleeve: place in GREEN bin (paper/cardboard ONLY)
notes: Paper coffee cups have a plastic lining that prevents recycling
Separate the lid (blue bin) and sleeve (green bin) from the cup (trash)
commonMistakes: Don't put the whole cup in the GREEN bin; the plastic lining makes the cup non-recyclable
Do recycle the plastic lid in the BLUE bin

materials.name: Frozen food boxes
instructions: Place in regular trash
Coated with a moisture barrier that prevents recycling
notes: The coating that prevents sogginess also prevents recycling; unlike regular paperboard
commonMistakes: Don't put these in the GREEN bin; they're not recyclable like regular cardboard

materials.name: Receipts (thermal paper)
instructions: Place in regular trash
Thermal paper contains BPA; do not recycle or compost
notes: If the receipt is shiny/smooth, it's thermal paper and goes in trash
Non-thermal receipts (matte paper) can go in the GREEN bin
commonMistakes: Don't put thermal receipts in the GREEN bin; they contaminate paper recycling with BPA
Don't compost thermal receipts

materials.name: Diapers
instructions: Place in regular trash
Wrap or bag soiled diapers before disposal
notes: Not recyclable or compostable
commonMistakes: Don't put diapers in any recycling or compost bin

materials.name: Ceramics, pottery, and dishware
instructions: Place in regular trash
Wrap broken pieces for safety
notes: Ceramics and pottery are NOT glass; they contaminate glass recycling
Consider donating intact dishware
commonMistakes: Don't put ceramics in the BLUE bin with glass; they're different materials
Don't put Pyrex or drinking glasses in recycling

materials.name: Mirrors and window glass
instructions: Wrap in newspaper or cardboard
Label 'GLASS' for safety of sanitation workers
Place in regular trash
notes: Mirrors and window glass have different melting points than bottle glass; they contaminate recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put mirrors or window glass in the BLUE bin

materials.name: Broken glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Label 'GLASS' or 'SHARP' on the outside for sanitation worker safety
Place in regular trash
notes: Broken glass is dangerous to sorting workers; never put it in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put broken glass in the BLUE bin; even if it was a recyclable bottle

materials.name: Plastic utensils
instructions: Place in regular trash
Too small and often contaminated for recycling
notes: Consider carrying reusable utensils. NYC restaurants must ask before including disposable ones
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic utensils in recycling

materials.name: Straws
instructions: Place in regular trash
Too small to be captured by recycling machinery
notes: Both plastic and paper straws go in trash; paper straws aren't efficiently composted at scale
Consider reusable straws
commonMistakes: Don't put straws in recycling or compost

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Place in regular trash
Wax coating prevents recycling
notes: Uncoated parchment paper can go in the brown bin (compost)
commonMistakes: Don't put wax paper in the GREEN bin

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Wire hangers: return to your dry cleaner for reuse
Plastic and wooden hangers: place in regular trash
Do NOT put any hangers in curbside recycling
notes: Hangers jam recycling machinery due to their shape
commonMistakes: Never put hangers in curbside recycling bins

materials.name: Pens, markers, and tape
instructions: Place in regular trash
Mixed materials; not recyclable curbside
notes: Some brands (like Crayola and BIC) offer mail-back recycling programs
commonMistakes: Don't put pens or markers in recycling

materials.name: Padded mailers and bubble envelopes
instructions: Place in regular trash
Mixed paper and plastic; cannot be separated for recycling
notes: Even paper-exterior padded mailers contain plastic bubble lining
commonMistakes: Don't put padded mailers in the GREEN bin; the plastic lining contaminates paper recycling

materials.name: Textiles and clothing
instructions: Place in a CLEAR bag and set out curbside on your recycling day
Or donate wearable items to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or Housing Works
Or drop off at GrowNYC Textile Recycling at greenmarket locations
notes: NYC accepts textiles curbside; place in a CLEAR (not black) bag on recycling day
Includes clothing, towels, sheets, curtains, and fabric in any condition
Even stained or torn textiles are accepted; they're recycled into rags or fiber
commonMistakes: Don't put textiles loose in the GREEN or BLUE bins
Don't use a black trash bag; must be a CLEAR bag so workers can identify it
Don't throw textiles in the trash if you can avoid it

materials.name: Shoes
instructions: Place in a CLEAR bag with other textiles and set out on recycling day
Or donate wearable shoes to Goodwill, Housing Works, or Salvation Army
Nike stores in NYC accept old athletic shoes
notes: Shoes count as textiles in NYC; accepted curbside in clear bags
commonMistakes: Don't put shoes in recycling bins
Tie pairs together when donating

materials.name: Damaged or worn-out clothing / textiles
instructions: Place in trash (black bag), or place in CLEAR bag with other textiles for NYC textile pickup if you prefer
Donate or use clear-bag textile pickup if still usable
notes: NYC accepts textiles in any condition in clear bags; if you cannot or prefer not to, trash is fine
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue or green recycling bins

materials.name: Electronics (e-waste)
instructions: Schedule FREE pickup with DSNY by calling 311 or visiting nyc.gov
Or drop off at the Lower East Side Ecology Center (e-waste events)
Or drop off at a DSNY Special Waste Drop-off site
notes: It is ILLEGAL to put electronics in NYC trash; there is a fine
DSNY offers free e-waste pickup; schedule online or by calling 311
Best Buy and Staples also accept some electronics for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in the trash; it's illegal in NYC and carries a fine
Don't put electronics in any curbside recycling bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Tape the terminals of lithium and 9-volt batteries to prevent fires
Drop off at a DSNY Special Waste Drop-off site or participating retailer
Call 311 to find the nearest drop-off location
Car batteries: bring to an auto parts store (they are required to accept them)
notes: Never put batteries in regular trash or recycling; they cause fires in garbage trucks
Many NYC stores (Staples, Home Depot, Best Buy) have battery drop-off bins
commonMistakes: Don't put batteries in any curbside bin; they cause fires
Don't forget to tape the terminals of 9V and lithium batteries

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Latex paint: dry it out (add kitty litter or sawdust), then place solidified paint in trash
Oil-based paint: bring to a DSNY Special Waste Drop-off site
Never pour paint down the drain
notes: Latex paint can go in trash once fully dried/solidified
Oil-based paint, stain, and varnish are hazardous and need drop-off
commonMistakes: Don't pour paint down the drain or toilet
Don't put liquid paint in the trash

materials.name: Fluorescent bulbs and CFLs
instructions: Bring to a DSNY Special Waste Drop-off site
Or drop off at participating Home Depot or IKEA stores
Handle carefully; these contain mercury
notes: Regular incandescent and LED bulbs go in the trash; only fluorescent/CFL bulbs are hazardous
commonMistakes: Don't put fluorescent bulbs in recycling or trash
Don't break them; they contain mercury vapor

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Bring to a DSNY Special Waste Drop-off site
Many auto parts stores (AutoZone, Pep Boys) accept used motor oil
Store in a sealed, leak-proof container for transport
notes: Never pour automotive fluids down storm drains, sewers, or in the trash
commonMistakes: Don't pour down the drain or storm sewer
Don't mix different automotive fluids together

materials.name: Propane tanks and compressed gas
instructions: Bring to a DSNY Special Waste Drop-off site
Small 1-lb camping propane canisters: must be completely empty, then place in BLUE bin
Full or partially full tanks: hazardous waste drop-off only
notes: Pressurized containers can explode in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Don't put propane tanks in regular trash
Don't puncture propane tanks

materials.name: Medications and pharmaceuticals
instructions: Drop off at an NYC pharmacy with a medication take-back program
Or bring to a DSNY Special Waste Drop-off site
If no drop-off available: mix pills with kitty litter or coffee grounds in a sealed bag, then trash
notes: Many NYC pharmacies have permanent drug take-back bins
Never flush medications; they contaminate the water supply
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications down the toilet
Don't put medications in recycling

materials.name: Light bulbs (LED and incandescent)
instructions: Wrap in paper or the original packaging
Place in regular trash
notes: Regular (non-fluorescent) bulbs are safe for trash
Fluorescent and CFL bulbs contain mercury and need hazardous waste drop-off
commonMistakes: Don't put light bulbs in recycling; they break and contaminate glass
Don't confuse with fluorescent/CFL bulbs which are hazardous

materials.name: Mattresses and bulk items
instructions: Schedule a free bulk pickup with DSNY by calling 311 or visiting nyc.gov
Mattresses must be sealed in a plastic bag before curbside pickup (NYC bedbug law)
Set out on your scheduled collection day
notes: NYC provides free curbside bulk pickup; just schedule in advance
Mattress encasement bags are available at hardware stores
commonMistakes: Don't leave mattresses or furniture on the curb without scheduling pickup first
Don't forget to bag mattresses in plastic

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts: absorb with newspaper or paper towels and place in BROWN bin (compost)
Large amounts: let solidify, scrape into brown bin or sealed container for drop-off
Never pour oil down the drain
notes: Some restaurants and drop-off sites accept large quantities of used cooking oil for biodiesel
commonMistakes: Never pour grease down the drain; it causes sewer blockages
Don't put liquid oil directly in the brown bin; absorb it first

materials.name: Rigid plastic cups
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
notes: Rigid plastic cups only; not foam cups (banned in NYC)
commonMistakes: Don't include styrofoam cups; those are banned and go in trash
Don't include cups with straws; remove straw (trash) and recycle cup (blue bin)

materials.name: Scrap metal
instructions: Small items: place in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
Large items (over 4 feet): schedule bulk pickup with 311
notes: NYC accepts scrap metal in the BLUE bin; pots, pans, small appliances without electronics
commonMistakes: Don't put large metal items in the blue bin; schedule bulk pickup instead

materials.name: Small appliances (non-electronic)
instructions: Place small metal appliances in BLUE bin (metal/glass/plastic/cartons)
If the appliance has a circuit board or screen, it's e-waste; schedule DSNY pickup instead
notes: Simple metal appliances (toasters, manual mixers) go in the blue bin
Anything with a digital display or computer chip is e-waste
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with electronics; if it has a screen or circuit board, it's e-waste

recycle: BLUE BIN: Plastic bottles and rigid containers (empty, clean, caps on)
BLUE BIN: Glass bottles and jars (empty, clean)
BLUE BIN: Aluminum and steel/tin cans (empty, clean)
BLUE BIN: Milk and juice cartons (Tetra Pak, gable-top)
BLUE BIN: Aluminum foil and trays (clean)
BLUE BIN: Aerosol cans (completely empty)
BLUE BIN: Rigid plastic cups, clamshells, and containers
BLUE BIN: Metal lids, caps, small scrap metal, pots and pans
GREEN BIN: Cardboard and corrugated boxes (flattened)
GREEN BIN: Newspapers, magazines, catalogs
GREEN BIN: Office paper, printer paper, notebook paper
GREEN BIN: Mail, envelopes, paper bags, books
GREEN BIN: Paperboard boxes (cereal, tissue, shoe boxes)
GREEN BIN: Wrapping paper (non-metallic), phone books
GREEN BIN: Shredded paper (in a paper bag)
compost: BROWN BIN: All food scraps including meat, bones, dairy
BROWN BIN: Fruit and vegetable peels, coffee grounds, tea bags
BROWN BIN: Food-soiled paper (napkins, paper towels, paper plates)
BROWN BIN: Yard waste, leaves, grass clippings
BROWN BIN: Houseplants, flowers, bread, pasta, rice
trash: Plastic film, bags, and wrap (return bags to store if possible)
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches
Ceramics, mirrors, window glass, broken glass

recycle: Plastic bags and flexible film; they jam machinery
Styrofoam; banned in NYC, goes in trash
Food waste; goes in brown compost bin
Ceramics, Pyrex, window glass, mirrors
Hangers of any type
Straws, plastic utensils
Padded mailers and bubble envelopes
Frozen food boxes (moisture-coated)
Disposable coffee cups (plastic-lined)

tips: NYC has a DUAL bin system: BLUE for metal/glass/plastic/cartons, GREEN for paper/cardboard only
Cartons (milk, juice, broth) go in BLUE; not GREEN; despite being made of paper
Styrofoam is banned citywide; it always goes in the trash
Textiles go curbside in a CLEAR bag on recycling day; or donate them
Electronics are illegal to trash; schedule free DSNY pickup via 311
Plastic bags go back to the store; never in curbside recycling
Rinse containers; they don't need to be spotless, just empty
Flatten cardboard to save space in the green bin
When in doubt, put it in the trash; contamination ruins entire truckloads
Pizza box trick: clean top in GREEN bin, greasy bottom in BROWN bin
Schedule bulk pickups (mattresses, furniture) via 311; it's free
Mattresses must be sealed in a plastic bag (NYC bedbug law)

locations.name: DSNY Special Waste Drop-off Sites
locations.notes: Multiple locations across NYC; call 311 or visit the website for the nearest site and hours

locations.name: Lower East Side Ecology Center
locations.notes: Also hosts regular e-waste collection events at Union Square and other Manhattan locations

locations.name: GrowNYC Textile Recycling
locations.notes: Drop-off available at various greenmarket locations across NYC; check website for schedule
